image.altText: In a sequence of images, a young Indigenous teen is held down and struck with a baton by police.

props.synopsis: 7.30 has obtained footage showing police beating an Indigenous youth repeatedly with a baton in a watch house, sparking allegations of excessive use of force.

title.children: 'Abhorrent and distressing': Multiple police beat teenager locked in watch house

image.altText: Jaymie Graham, Dean Cox and Ashley Hansen must be considered

props.synopsis: After the departure of a premiership coach, the West Coast Eagles will begin the search for a replacement immediately and, with a host of young talent on their list, the club's next appointment needs to be spot on.

title.children: After 11 years of Adam Simpson, who'll be next to step into the West Coast Eagles hot seat?

image.altText: Filicide study

props.synopsis: About 20 children are murdered by a parent every year in Australia. It's a crime that evokes equal measures of horror and confusion. At the crux of the issue is male perpetrated violence.

title.children: 'The ultimate form of revenge': The psychology behind acts of filicide

image.altText: Tourists look at the Eiffel Tower from afar. One girl is wearing a red beret and another is holding up an iphone.

props.synopsis: The Australian dollar is gaining strength and that can influence everything from the pace of inflation to the cost of your next overseas trip.

title.children: Fancy travelling overseas? Here's why now could be a cheaper time to do it

image.altText: New research examines prevalence of sexual violence perpetration in Australia

props.synopsis: A new study finds "shocking" levels of perpetrating sexual violence among Australians aged 18 to 45, with men the main offenders.

title.children: 1 in 5 Australians admit to perpetrating acts of sexual violence, from harassing someone for a date to sexual assault

image.altText: A bespectacled man with a grey goatee wears a blue top as he sits with his arms on a table in front of him.

props.synopsis: Within a year of landing her first full-time teaching job, Oh Jae Geun's daughter took her own life after overzealous parents ruthlessly scrutinised her performance and threatened to make criminal complaints to the police.

title.children: Oh Jae Geun's daughter was a teacher. After her death, he found shocking stories about parents in her diary

image.altText: Mikayla Hinkley smiling wearing her orange Scorchers shirt with the Australian and Aboriginal flags in the background.

props.synopsis: Cricket hasn't just provided Mikayla Hinkley with a sporting career, it's also allowed her to connect with her Indigenous heritage and become a role model for aspiring athletes.

title.children: How this Perth Scorchers batter is helping attract more Indigenous athletes into playing cricket

image.altText: Narendra Modi and Vladimir Putin shake hands while smiling in front of an Indian and Russian flag

props.synopsis: Narendra Modi's pointed remarks came just moments after he was welcomed to the Kremlin by Vladimir Putin.

title.children: 'The heart bleeds': Indian PM condemns deaths of children in war while meeting Vladimir Putin

image.altText: Police outside a house

props.synopsis: A 45-year-old man has been charged with murder after a woman's body was found at a waste management facility in Melbourne's north last week.

title.children: Man charged with murdering woman whose body was found at a waste facility in Melbourne's north

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing a beanie squatting in the sun in front of a red building

props.synopsis: As Alice Springs approaches its third and potentially final night of a snap 72-hour curfew, frontline services say they're deeply concerned for those sleeping rough.

title.children: Alice Springs curfew targeting crime exposes underlying homelessness crisis, services say

image.altText: A star which looks like a firework.

props.synopsis: A spectacular nova may be about to light up our night sky in the constellation Corona Borealis. If it does, Australians will only have a short window to catch it.

title.children: Just after WWII ended, the 'Blaze Star' exploded. Astronomers say it's about to happen again

image.altText: Tennis player Alex de Minaur gives the thumbs up in front of the Wimbledon crowd.

props.synopsis: Alex de Minaur has become "a different player" in the 18 months since he got rolled by Novak Djokovic in their last grand slam contest. Their Wimbledon contest will be the ultimate chance for the Australia's number one to take down a living legend.

title.children: 'Honorary Brit' Alex de Minaur set for ultimate challenge against Wimbledon heel Novak Djokovic

image.altText: A woman looks out a window toward a garden.

props.synopsis: If you've had concerns about a loved one's drug use and haven't known how to help them, you're not alone — new research shows most people don't know where to start.

title.children: Watching a loved one struggle with drug use can be 'devastating and terrifying'. Here's how to help

image.altText: Brent Wyndham in police uniform walking next to another policeman outside Geraldton courthouse.

props.synopsis: An inquest into the police shooting death of a WA woman is told it would have been reasonable to expect officers could have resolved the confrontation without lethal force.

title.children: 'Expectation' police could have avoided lethal force in woman's shooting, inquest told

image.altText: FRIDGE ALEX ADELE

props.synopsis: Victorian couple Adele and Alex Rae say they were exposed to a "really strong" chemical smell coming from their Samsung fridge, which caused Ms Rae to collapse. They've been offered a refund on the condition they never talk about it again.

title.children: The Raes say their fridge malfunctioned, triggering illness, and their refund offer included a 'gag clause'

image.altText: A collage of photos shows a range of unique underwater creatures.

props.synopsis: Ever wondered what the ocean floor around Australia's coast looks like? A first-of-its-kind survey has uncovered new information about underwater canyons.

title.children: First-of-its-kind survey of the ocean floor discovers 'submarine canyons' full of unique marine life

image.altText: The prime minister shakes the hand of a young woman

props.synopsis: Being nominated for Australian of the Year is one of the most rewarding experiences, as SA's Tiahni Adamson can attest. With nominations closing at the end of the month, those working behind the scenes offer a glimpse into the long process of choosing an overall winner.

title.children: Choosing between 'everyday Australians doing extraordinary things' is no easy feat for those running our national awards

image.altText: An older Aboriginal man in a cowboy hat sits in a wheelchair, bright paintings behind him. He's wearing a red London jumper

props.synopsis: This year, Adrian Jangala Robertson became the first Aboriginal artist to be a finalist for the Archibald, Wynne and Sulman prizes in the same year. Now he's taking his art overseas.

title.children: This artist is bringing his the bright colours of the central desert to the art galleries of London

image.altText: Professional boxer striking opponent in boxing ring as opponent attempts to block

props.synopsis: Alex Winwood has achieved plenty in his 11-year boxing career, but standing up in front of 1,800 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as sportsperson of the year is a moment he'll never forget.

title.children: Bunbury-born boxer wins top NAIDOC sports award as he eyes off world champion ranking

image.altText: A pile of floppy disks.

props.synopsis: Japan's government finally eliminates the use of floppy disks in all its systems, two decades after the technology's heyday.

title.children: 'We have won the war on floppy disks': Japanese government erases outdated technology from systems

image.altText: Jasper Philipsen  pumps his fist on his bike as he celebrates winning Tour de France 10th stage.

props.synopsis: The Belgian benefited from a perfect lead-out by Alpecin-Deceuninck teammate and world champion Mathieu van der Poel to prevail after 187.3 kilometres from Orleans.

title.children: Philipsen finally bags Tour de France stage win as Pogačar stays in control

image.altText: A woman in a pink jumper reads to a small child.

props.synopsis: Living in a childcare desert has meant Sarah and Jacob Vlatko have had to devise a creative work schedule to care for their toddler, but they're concerned it will have flow-on effects for her superannuation.

title.children: Without access to childcare, Sarah is one of thousands of mums whose superannuation is taking a hit

image.altText: Chinese flags fly high outside the Australian Parliament House in Canberra

props.synopsis: Australia and key regional partners are accusing a Chinese spy agency of cyber espionage targeting government and business networks, in a large-scale operation that involves stealing hundreds of usernames and passwords.

title.children: Australia takes lead for first time in pushback against Chinese hacking

image.altText: West Coast Eagles coach Adam Simpson

props.synopsis: Eagles coach Adam Simpson will leave West Coast after weeks of pressure on his leadership, with the club saying they have mutually agreed his 11-year tenure will come to an end.

title.children: Adam Simpson gone as West Coast Eagles coach after more than a decade at helm

image.altText: HDML 1321 in Hobart

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory government says it will "dispose of" a historic Huon pine warship used by the elite Z Special Group in World War Two. A group of enthusiasts is hoping to save the rotting vessel, but time is running out.

title.children: 'It would be a travesty': Historic Huon pine warship set to be 'disposed of'

image.altText: football players bending over with hands on knees, looking tired and defeated

props.synopsis: Regional clubs have proposed radical changes to save community football including banning player payments altogether or introducing a new player points system.

title.children: Country football dying a 'slow death' with thousand-dollar player payments blamed for killing the game

image.altText: Kate Lawrence stands next to a student at a circus training class

props.synopsis: The Adelaide Fringe is booming, selling more than a million tickets two years in a row. But some performers are questioning whether the festival has become too big — leaving local shows lost in the crowd.

title.children: Veteran performer quits Adelaide Fringe, saying it's now 'financially unviable' for independent artists

image.altText: Dozens of people holding up the roof of a building crumbling down after a missile strike

props.synopsis: Msocow has claimed a Kyiv children's hospital was hit by Ukrainian anti-missile fire, not a Russian missile, during daylight attacks that killed 41 people across the country.

title.children: 'Horrific reminder of Russia's brutality': Kyiv children's hospital bombed as strikes kill dozens across Ukraine

image.altText: Man in dirty Sydney Swans uniform rests hands on hips

props.synopsis: Sydney Swans' Isaac Heeney is ineligible for the Brownlow Medal after failing to overturn his one-game ban at the AFL tribunal.

title.children: Brownlow contender Isaac Heeney fails to overturn ban

image.altText: Dirty money house 2

props.synopsis: The Australian government's efforts to crack down on money laundering is facing resistance from certain professions, but failing to do so is leaving the nation well behind the global fight against these financial crimes.

title.children: Can the government beat the real estate industry in its money laundering crackdown?

image.altText: Two men walking away from the NT Local Court.

props.synopsis: Neil Mellon has been sentenced to eight months behind bars after pleading guilty to a string of offences, including destroying evidence related to a 2022 helicopter crash that killed Netflix star Chris ‘Willow’ Wilson.

title.children: Former NT police officer jailed for destroying evidence after chopper crash that killed Netflix star

image.altText: A frying pan sits on a city street, with an egg inside it.

props.synopsis: Four people were reported dead in the Portland area and one at Death Valley, California, due to the gripping heat.

title.children: A searing heat wave has gripped the US, leaving five dead in California and Oregon

image.altText: A humpback whale is freed from trawler wire near Iluka on the NSW north coast.

props.synopsis: A 'hand-picked' team of divers braved big swells to free a humpback whale pinned to the ocean floor off the NSW North Coast.

title.children: Juvenile humpback was 'anchored to sea floor' by a wire cable for 8 days before dramatic rescue
